factoid: The woman said, "No, it will not do."
The woman clasped her hands.
The woman said, "No, Mary, really this dress does not suit you."
The woman said, "I prefer you in your little gray everyday dress."
The woman said, "Now please, do it for my sake."
The woman said to Katie, "bring the princess her gray dress, and you’ll see, Mademoiselle Bourienne, how I shall arrange it."
The woman smiled with a foretaste of artistic pleasure.
Katie brought the required dress.
Princess Mary remained sitting motionless before the glass.
Princess Mary looked at her face in the mirror.
Princess Mary saw in the mirror that her eyes were full of tears.
Princess Mary's mouth was quivering, ready to burst into sobs.
Mademoiselle Bourienne said, "Come, dear princess, just one more little effort."
The little princess took the dress from the maid.
The little princess came up to Princess Mary.
Mademoiselle Bourienne said, "Well, now we’ll arrange something quite simple and becoming."
The voices of the little princess, Mademoiselle Bourienne, and Katie mingled in a merry sound.
Katie was laughing at something.
Princess Mary said, "No, leave me alone."
Princess Mary's voice sounded serious and sad.
The chirping of the birds was silenced at once.
Princess Mary's eyes were beautiful, large, thoughtful, full of tears and thoughts.
Princess Mary's eyes gazed shiningly and imploringly at the other voices.
The other voices understood that it was useless and cruel to insist.
The little princess said, "At least, change your coiffure."
The little princess said, "Didn’t I tell you, Mary's face is a face which such a coiffure does not suit in the least."
The little princess said, "Not in the least!"
The little princess said, "Please change it."
The voice of Princess Mary answered, "Leave me alone, please leave me alone! It is all quite the same to me."
Mademoiselle Bourienne and the little princess realized that Princess Mary looked very plain in this guise.
Princess Mary's expression was thoughtful and sad.
Princess Mary's expression did not frighten Mademoiselle Bourienne and the little princess.
When Princess Mary's expression appeared, Princess Mary became mute and was not to be shaken in her determination.
Lise said, "You will change it, won’t you?"
Princess Mary gave no answer.
Lise left the room.
Princess Mary was left alone.
Princess Mary did not comply with Lise’s request.
Princess Mary left her hair as it was.
Princess Mary did not look in her glass.
Princess Mary let her arms fall helplessly.
Princess Mary sat with downcast eyes.
Princess Mary pondered.
In Princess Mary's imagination, a husband, a man, a strong dominant and strangely attractive being rose.
The imagined husband carried Princess Mary into a totally different happy world of his own.
Princess Mary fancied a child, her own, similar to the one she had seen the day before in the arms of her nurse’s daughter.
The imagined husband stood by and gazed tenderly at Princess Mary and the child.
Princess Mary thought, "But no, it is impossible, I am too ugly."
The maid said, "Please come to tea. The prince will be out in a moment."
